comments.commentBody:
Oh, God.

Anyone who can read this without a tear welling up in an eye is truly hard hearted. I'm so sorry that this love story is working out this way. Thank you for writing it.
The "fellow" (Jason) is a lawyer!!
Dear carailk. May YOU live a long happy life. The last two lines of your post made me cry, just like Ms Rosenthal 's essay. This world needs more kind hearted souls like both you and AKR.
Oh, get over yourself. You know nothing about her husband.
Please stop with the "don't give up" garbage. Medicine doesn't heal the soul.
Stop, stop, stop!!! Everyone's journey is different.

Dearest Amy,
I'm writing this through my tears. Your touching love letter tells us not just how good and kind and sensitive and talented a husband Jason is, but how incredible and loving you are as his wife, as a human being. You're a very courageous woman. I've never read your books but I sure will. Look what you've engendered by sharing your story. All the comments say basically the same thing..... Yayyyyyy, and we love you, beautiful Amy.

Amy,

Although I'm single and in the Chicagoland area, I can only hope for your good health to return. You two sound like you have a idyllic relationship that no other woman could fulfill. The fact that you wrote this article shows the pure love you have for Jason. I am so sorry that you are going through this, but I have friends who have actually rebounded and that is what I hope for you. Know that you have support here in Chicago and that I make a mean matzo ball soup that got my friend through many rounds of chemo.

April
Amy. Valentines day has been and gone but I truly hope you are not and that you are still with us next Valentines day. Fingers crossed for you.
No hostility for you, Lisa, just compassion. May you find moments of sunshine and peace.

I feel the love you have for your husband, that love comes from God. I'm sorry we have to suffer in life, we never know what will come our way, until it does. I wanted to read your article throughout, mostly because I like your positive outlook even dealing with cancer, but also because what a beautiful, selfless, loving gift that shows the extent of your love for your husband. I'm sure he cried as well when he read this. I will pray for you, and your husband, and please know if you seek God and accept his Son, you will someday both be together once again. God Bless you, take care and have peace in knowing Christ. Amen.
Kristi, I know you mean well, but please don't presume everyone's peace is through seeking/knowing Christ.

I believe it is really in appropriate to introduce religious doctrine into these comments when it played no part in Ms. Rosenthal's touching essay.

And I believe it is both inappropriate and insensitive to prescribe last-minute Jesus to a dying woman who is Jewish.

But I suppose there's a good reason for the old saying that "to a hammer, everything looks like a nail."
I believe she mentioned his law degree and career his 9-5 job at his law office. Don't you think that's a bit insensitive and rude. Some things you should keep to yourself.
I may want to, he sounds like an amazing person. Lol. You are beautiful Amy and thank you for sharimg.

Dear Amy, You just might make it.  I hope so.  I have a friend who had Ovarian Cancer many years ago. She's still here.  You sound so special and your letter so  heartbreaking, I can't stop crying and I am wishing for you, a reprieve.

Dearest Amy
Do not give up , never give up till the end and fight as your will to live the life you described is more powerful then any cancer.
Believe in miracles no matter what médecine says as we always say in médecine , when a patient decide to live the medicine is hopeless.

Sending you tones of positive energy to strengthen your immune system to fight

Warmly

This is not strictly true. GE tried to build a business of coal-fired Integrated combined-cycle ... GE really gave it their best.

The problem is that you cannot put coal ash through a gas turbine -- eats the turbine for breakfast. So what you need to do is build an integrated gasifier, converting the coal to CO + H2, scrub out all the ash and the ugly stuff (mercury, sulfur oxides, some other rarer species) and then burn that in the gas turbine of the combined-cycle system.

Nobody wants to buy -- the costs don't make any sense.

Coal is dead. Natural gas and renewables have won, they are a lot cheaper.

It's this brutal set of facts that the utilities understand, and the coal partisans don't: wind power and now even solar-power (both at good sites) are considerably cheaper in life-cycle costs than coal-fired plants, and also have considerably less economic risk.

Eastern US coal is particularly DOA.

Hi Amy,
Today I watched the sun warm the clothesline so much that icicles melted. I sense that's the warmth you feel when you think about your husband. I could hear the trees crack from the cold and I sense you have that sharp response when he is with you and your togetherness is alive and charging. I tasted the tanginess of rhubarb coddled oats and I sense that is your spirited nature bursting and appreciated by your nurturing husband.
Ahh matchmaker, matchmaker, trying to match, seeking his mate
Be still in your loveliness, dwell in this state
Know that you are and always will be
Someone he loves, with him always, forever his Amy.
Love to you, the giver of loveliness.

Wow. I am pretty much at the same stage of life and family. Unlike you, I hold my life rather loosely, feeling little connection to the world or to those I have cared for most deeply. I have never felt particularly happy or loved. I have felt useful, though, and needed. I am a very useful and hard working person. I know I have made a difference for many people, so I guess that is something worthwhile. But life is just another day at work for me. The sun rises and sets, and sometimes I am struck by its beauty.

Your gift is to be so fiercely in love with your life that you never want to let go. That really is something that most people never have. Most people don't love life, they merely fear death. May God bless you, though it seems you are already blessed.

A piece of you will remain within all of your readers - your honesty, wit, and connection to Jason. Thank you. Your love for Jason will wake him up each morning and put him to sleep at night. No matter whom he meets, you'll always be tucked within his heart. May the remaining days, minutes and seconds of your pulse be infused with the love and humor you have shared with all of us.
With love, peace, big hugs, and a restful journey,
Amy
I just read your article and I am so saddened by your illness. Cancer strikes indescriminately.  I hope that you have faith that you will be with Jason for eternity in heaven.

Please, give me a break. I married the perfect woman. Neither of us seems ready to give up the ghost, but she did get me through a brain tumor. I think the perfect partner is MADE by the perfect partner. I know we were made for each other. We just took 33 years to find each other. So he is losing the perfect wife. Cry for him. That is the way it is.

Sorry to see you go.
Right, very cruel.  I just do not understand such heartlessness.
Unnelievably insensitive. Well, two can be rude you know. You sure you got cured of that brain tumor?
One of a very few stories about love that actually made me cringe.

I can only imagine the "dating profile" your j would write for you.  I can tell from his bio that you are  the beautiful lid to his perfect pot.   How moving and touching your constant and undying love for him is.  You are the definition of true love.

As a fellow children's book author and Amy, and, someone who has admired your work from afar, most importantly, your incredibly lovely, extraordinary, joyful and generous spirit, I am just heartbroken. Thank you for inspiring me and reminding me to beckon lovely and to embrace plan be. That is a life's work. I know I am not alone in feeling this way. You touch many. You are loved. Bon voyage.

I want to give you a gift. A story. Another marriage similar to yours is in my thoughts. The husband was dying. It was not a matter of "if" but "when" ... the couple stopped measuring time and focused on the quality of the love they shared. The husband passed away, his wife ... mmmm, let's say she took a while to move forward, but really, it was the time she needed to comprehend just want they had been through together. She took one day at a time. When well-meaning friends told her how strong she had been ... she remembered how strong her husband had been. Much stronger than she. A long story kept short by design, here in this comment. But recently, she told me she had found a special dish that he had kept. When she found it, she knew exactly why he had kept it. The special dish was from his parents' estate ... engraved "25th Anniversary" ... he had kept it, planning to be around for their 25th celebration. But finding the dish after his passing held just as much if not more meaning. He had planned to be there for their 25th. By keeping the dish, he expressed his love ... and when she found it, she knew. So, my gift to you ... love each other and forget time. Love.
My heart goes out ot you. Thank you
